entry.title: Bott = Planck = sheared Rees, part iii

link.title: Bott = Planck = sheared Rees, part iii

entry.content:
We will pick up straight from last time.

Part three: /the trusty circle

So far, we have seen that the in -connections (which encodes the Hodge filtration) should be viewed as from deformation quantization/Bogomolov-Tian-Todorov, which we saw is the same thing as the Bott element. In this post, I would like to take this one step further, and argue that the Bott class is/should be the key object around which the stories of quantization and filtrations/Rees objects revolves. (I’m certain that this is something that experts like Kontsevich know, but it’s been pretty hard to track down references where this is explicitly said.) One of the reasons for this perspective is that the Bott class admits a canonical “lift to the sphere spectrum”, and as such tells us how to approach quantization and friends in characteristic (or, more generally, over any structured ring spectrum).

To motivate this perspective, let us look at the Bogomolov-Tian-Todorov theorem and Hodge-de Rham degeneration in characteristic , as a way of inching closer to the universal base . There’s a version of BTT for Calabi-Yaus in characteristic , albeit under some rather strong assumptions: the Calabi-Yau should lift to the Witt vectors, and the de Rham cohomology of this lift should be free (well, this is almost the condition). Using the perspective on BTT as coming from the triviality of the -action on Hochschild homology that we described in our last post, it is possible to extend Schroer’s result to the milder assumptions that is larger than the dimension of our Calabi-Yau , and that lifts to .

These assumptions also showed up in work of Deligne-Illusie, where (in one of my favorite papers ever) they showed that these assumptions on (not necessarily Calabi-Yau, just smooth and proper over a perfect field of characteristic ) implies that the Hodge-de Rham spectral sequence degenerates. We already saw in the previous post that the relationship between (the parameter keeping track of the Hodge filtration) and the Bott element manifests itself as the relationship between the Hodge-de Rham spectral sequence and the Tate spectral sequence for Hochschild homology; therefore, one might expect that for certain smooth and proper -linear stable presentable -categories, the Tate spectral sequence for Hochschild homology degenerates. This is in fact the case, and a readable exposition is here.

(The careful reader might notice that the situation might actually be slightly worse than in the characteristic zero case, where the problem stems not from the Tate or Hodge-de Rham spectral sequences, but rather from the HKR spectral sequence. In characteristic zero, the HKR spectral sequence degenerated at , and so we could conclude from our square of spectral sequences that the Tate spectral sequence degenerates for if and only if the Hodge-de Rham spectral sequence degenerates. As it turns out, though, the HKR spectral sequence need not degenerate at the -page for arbitrary smooth proper -schemes. It does degenerate, however, once . This is one of the Deligne-Illusie assumptions, and so if those conditions are satisfied, then the Tate spectral sequence degenerates if and only if the Hodge-de Rham spectral sequence degenerates.)

We can then ask for a categorified version of Hodge theory (i.e., nonabelian Hodge theory) in characteristic . We briefly discussed this here, so the reader should read that post. The restrictions on the nilpotence order there are nothing but categorifications of the Deligne-Illusie conditions; see section 2.5 in Ogus-Vologodsky for the precise conditions. Given that the Hodge filtration is measured by , and , we can finally ask for a “-periodic version” of the nonabelian Hodge correspondence in characteristic . Again, we discussed this here, so I’ll refer the reader there again, rather than repeat what I wrote.

It will be important for our discussion to note that the non-degeneration of the HKR spectral sequence means that Hochschild homology in characteristic is not necessarily formal (as an --algebra). In other words, is not equivalent to . The -action on is supposed to give the de Rham differential on — but unlike in characteristic zero, the datum of a differential is not equivalent to an -action. This is because is not equivalent to as an -ring; in other words, is not formal.

This is a very important fact to remember. There is a way to fix this, described in this paper: rather than worrying about proving formality, one just keeps track of the entire Whitehead filtration, and works in the world of filtered --algebras. (If the algebras under consideration are formal, then the Whitehead filtration collapses, and so this amounts to just working in graded -algebras.) In particular, rather than trying (and failing, because it’s not true) to prove formality of Hochschild homology with its -action in characteristic , we should just work with the filtered object with the action of instead. The associated graded of this is with its -action by the de Rham differential.

The HKR spectral sequence collapses in characteristic in some cases, namely when . This means that there can’t be a -differential if , and that Hochschild homology is formal for these schemes. The -action is also formal, in the following sense: under the equivalence , we can view with its -action (at least, as a Borel -spectrum) as a -module. Now, is the -Koszul dual of , and so the non-formality of is the same as the non-formality of . The desired formality statement is then that even though is not formal, it is formal through a range: the --algebra is formal.

Before we proceed, let us briefly digress to discuss the characteristic analogue of Kontsevich’s result. Again, the HKR spectral sequence collapses in characteristic in some cases. In characteristic zero, the HKR spectral sequence collapsing was the first step (literally, the first Taylor approximation) to Kontsevich’s quasi-isomorphism between the Hochschild cohomology dg-Lie algebra and its homotopy (the algebra of polyvector fields). We saw that this formality stems from the rational formality of the -operad. I recently came across this paper, which says that the -operad is formal through a range. In particular, Corollary A of this paper should lead to a proof of:

Informal Conjecture: Kontsevich formality (i.e., is equivalent as a dg-Lie algebra to its homotopy) holds for smooth proper schemes over a perfect field of characteristic for which .

Let’s now return to the main program. We’ve seen that, in characteristic zero, the Bott class is just the filtration parameter , which in turn is the deformation quantization parameter . However, this fails in a sense in characteristic : we have seen that the Bott class is really a consequence of having an -action (e.g., is a -module because acts on ). However, because is not formal, we cannot really say that the Bott class “lives in” , only that it lives in . Since, in characteristic , we cannot get by with only knowing the action of (which is sufficient in characteristic zero by formality), we really need to keep track of the entire -action. This allows to finally arrive at the thesis of these posts:

Slogan: The datum of an -action on an object is the homotopical version of the datum of a filtration. Moreover, the triviality of this -action is analogous to the existence of a deformation quantization. (The first sentence relates and , while the second relates and .)

We can make this slogan a little more precise, but to do so, we need to revisit something we briefly mentioned at the end of the previous post. Recall that if is a filtered -algebra, then the Rees construction is the filtered -module . In other words, powers of keep track of the filtration on . Therefore, ccording to our equation , powers of should keep track of a filtration on the homotopy fixed points of an -action on . This filtration isn’t terribly surprising: it is exactly the filtration coming from the homotopy fixed points spectral sequence

(Note that if is a -algebra, then the -page is .) This filtration is exactly the resulting -adic filtration on . We said above that the action of on isn’t really “sufficient” for studying -actions away from characteristic zero, so we should be looking for a homotopical version of the -adic filtration on a -module .

Luckily, we already know of such a thing: just look at the filtration on induced by the filtration

Computing the effect on homotopy shows that this is indeed a homotopical refinement of the -adic filtration. This allows us to arrive at the following refined slogan.

Slightly refined slogan: An -action on a -module gives rise to the “-filtration” on , and the resulting filtration on homotopy is analogous to the datum of a filtration. Moreover, the triviality of this -action is analogous to the existence of a deformation quantization.

One very appealing aspect of this slogan is that the -filtration is not only defined on -modules with an -action, but on all spectra with an -action. In other words, this slogan allows us to study “deformation quantization over the sphere spectrum”.

Before we get too excited, there are some subtleties that we need to discuss. First, if is a -module with an -action, we get a filtered -module , as described above. However, as discussed here, the filtered spectrum over an arbitrary -ring will only be a filtered -ring spectrum via the diagonal on , and not a filtered -ring (or even a filtered -ring, although Lurie only states this and doesn’t prove it).

Next, one might be a tad bit surprised to see the claim that “modules over ” are supposed to be homotopical versions of filtrations, for the following reason. If is the category of graded spectra and the category of filtered spectra, then there is a canonical -algebra such that modules over in graded spectra are filtered spectra. Indeed, just let the th graded piece of be if , and zero if . The action of “” (which generates the copy of in graded degree ) on the graded spectrum gives the transition maps necessary to get a filtered spectrum out of the graded spectrum.

On the other hand, modules over (or, rather, ) in graded spectra are graded -modules along with maps . We see that looks rather different from : in a sense, it is a “sheared” version of . This was mentioned at the end of the previous post, where we said that fixing the grading in the nonabelian Hodge correspondence (to get the Rees variable to live in degree ) is a sort of shearing procedure. We can now see why this isn’t exactly how one should be thinking of the passage from -modules: for instance, while is a filtered -ring, is only ; moreover, it’s not obvious how one might start with a filtered spectrum and then “shear” it.

Nonetheless, the passage isn’t completely mysterious: the underlying object of is the suspension spectrum , and this is an augmented -algebra. We can then take its 2-fold bar construction (i.e., the -Koszul dual), and this gives . All of this works in the filtered setting, too: if is given the filtration , then the -Koszul dual in filtered spectra is .

At this point, it is apt to remark that the connection between deformation quantization and the fact that is the -Koszul dual of has already been studied by many. See, for instance, Theorem 5.1 in Toen’s 2014 ICM address: if is a field of characteristic zero, the deformation theory of a compactly generated -linear dg-category is controlled by the Hochschild cohomology of , and deformations of to are the same as -module structures on . We can now see that our slogan allows us to generalize Toen’s statement to arbitary -rings : the deformation theory of a compactly generated -linear presentable stable -category is controlled by the Hochschild cohomology, and deformations of to are the same as -linear structures on , or rather -linear presentable stable -categories with an -action such that . Because is the associated graded of the -filtration on , and it is in characteristic zero, this reduces to Toen’s result in characteristic zero. The above statement, however, works for any -ring, and hence in particular for any field (regardless of characteristic).

In the next post, we will explore what happens in characteristic . Let’s end this post with a remark. In previous posts, we focused primarily on what happens when we set (which corresponds to going from quantum mechanics to classical mechanics) and (which corresponds to taking the associated graded). However, it is common in quantum mechanics to set — this goes by the name “natural units”. Our main equation tells us that this corresponds to setting in the filtered world; this just means “working with the underlying unfiltered object”. Unfortunately, in the homotopical world, it doesn’t really make sense to “set to ”, because lives in degree 2, while lives in degree 0. But this isn’t that big of a deal: we can just invert instead, and this amounts to taking the Tate construction in -homotopy theory. We’ve already seen this perspective in action in this post, where we argued that a homotopical version of the (characteristic ) nonabelian Hodge correspondence is really supposed to be a Frobenius-linear equivalence between a certain subcategory of and , where is a -linear stable presentable category and denotes its -center.

entry.title: Bott = Planck = sheared Rees, part ii

link.title: Bott = Planck = sheared Rees, part ii

entry.content:
We will pick up straight from last time.

Part two: /Hodge theory

Let us focus on Kontsevich’s fact that the Hochschild cochains are formal, rather than the fact that the -operad is formal. There is a version of Kontsevich’s result in complex geometry, and it is due to Bogomolov-Tian-Todorov: if is a Calabi-Yau variety, then the Hochschild cochains on , equipped with the (shifted) Lie bracket structure, is (quasi-isomorphic to) a formal abelian dg-Lie algebra. (This is usually stated in more classical language as the fact that deformations of Calabi-Yaus are unobstructed and smooth, even though the deformation groups are nonzero. This can be viewed as the complex analytic version of Kontsevich’s statement, because the condition of orientability (i.e., having a nowhere vanishing -form) is replaced with being Calabi-Yau (i.e., having a nowhere vanishing holomorphic -form).) I wrote up some notes about this here. I’m going to focus on the BTT theorem rather than Kontsevich’s theorem (because it’s conceptually easier for me), but ultimately we’re just going to be talking about formality. One nice thing about BTT which I like is that working in the complex analytic world gives us a bit more structure, and makes some formulae more transparent.

I will state an abstract version of the BTT theorem (in terms of dg-Lie algebras); specializing to the Kodaira-Spencer dg-Lie algebra with the Lie bracket of vector fields and differential given by will give the BTT theorem. (Note the distinction from the smooth case, where the differential was just zero.) The additional structure of a volume form on the Calabi-Yau variety gives a degree operator , by contracting with , applying , and contracting with (the dual of) . This makes the Kodaira-Spencer dg-Lie algebra into a dg-BV-algebra: the bracket is actually given by the Gerstenhaber bracket

this statement is called the Tian-Todorov lemma, and is the key complex analytic input into the BTT theorem.

Let be a dg-BV-algebra, with BV-operator (of degree ). The above equation for the bracket makes into a dg-Lie algebra, and we can then “quantize” in the land of dg-Lie algebras: if is an element of degree , then we get a new dg-Lie algebra (which I denoted by in my notes here, for the same reason that I’m writing this post), where the Lie bracket is just induced from , and where the differential is . (Haven’t we seen this before somewhere? Hmm…) Also, I didn’t know about this paper when writing my notes on BTT, but see also here. There is a -adic spectral sequence

Then, the modern rephrasing of the BTT theorem states: is quasi-isomorphic to a formal dg-Lie algebra with trivial Lie bracket if and only if the -adic spectral sequence degenerates at . (Haven’t we also seen this before somewhere? Hmm…)

For example, if and satisfy the analogue of the --lemma (see Theorem 2.3.4 in my notes), then it’s very easy to argue this result directly. Because it’s cute, I want to recall a proof (Proposition 4.1.9 in my notes) that if the -adic spectral sequence degenerates at , then is (quasi-isomorphic to) abelian. First, it is fairly easy to directly argue that degeneration implies that is formal. So to show abelianness, we can invert . Define a map on the degree elements in by

It suffices to show that there is some automorphism of (i.e., coordinate reindexing/change of basis) such that . The idea is to look at

Then, one can just calculate:

(It’s strange that is essentially the inverse of the Bernoulli series.)

I’d like to move on to other things in a moment, but I want to just pause and summarize the story so far. Quantization in physics is, from the Heisenberg point of view, a deformation of classical mechanics, and Kontsevich proved that such quantizations always exist for smooth (closed, oriented) manifolds with a given Poisson structure. This has an algebraic/complex analytic analogue, given by the Bogomolov-Tian-Todorov theorem. Both the BTT theorem and Kontsevich’s theorem are given by the formality (and abelianness) of Hochschild homology, which we have seen is essentially the same as the degeneration of the -adic spectral sequence.

We will now pick up from the degneration of the -adic spectral sequence, and our formula for the differential on . Let’s first focus on the differential. Recall that a mixed complex is a dg-module over . Recall that we’re in characteristic zero, so . Therefore, a mixed complex is just a chain complex with a square-zero map of degree . (I cannot believe that I’m using cohomological grading.) The homotopy fixed points of this -action is a chain complex, given by . We can write down a resolution of as a -module, and we find that is equivalent to the complex , where is the degree element in

But necessarily acts trivially, so is just the Bott class in .

It might be better to denote by , because this obviously looks a whole lot like the differential on . We also see the first part of our equation () in action. What does the degeneration of the -adic spectral sequence then translate to? It is easy to see that the -adic spectral sequence is exactly the homotopy fixed points spectral sequence

and the degeneration of the -adic spectral sequence at the -page is just the degeneration of the homotopy fixed points spectral sequence (HFPSS) at the -page. (One might be a little worried by the fact that we went from an -page to an -page, but this makes no real difference.)

Before proceeding, I would like to make an observation. The BV-operator has now appeared in a two different forms. In the deformation quantization story, it came from the (framed) -algebra structure on Hochschild cohomology, while in the picture we’re describing right now, it comes from an -action. We’ll discuss the link in the next post.

Returning to our main story: one of the most important algebraic examples of a mixed complex is Hochschild homology: if is a smooth variety, then is a mixed complex with the usual -action. In this case, what does degeneration of the HFPSS mean? For this, we turn to our trusty tool, the HKR theorem. We know that has a filtration obtained from the HKR filtration such that the th graded piece is . It’s easier to work with the Tate spectral sequence, going from to the homotopy of ; this degenerates iff the HFPSS degenerates, so we might as well look at the degeneration of the Tate spectral sequence. The HKR filtration extends to a filtration on whose th associated graded is The Tate SS going from to is a 2-periodic version of the Hodge-de Rham spectral sequence, and its degeneration can be viewed as a 2-periodic version of the rational degeneration of the Hodge-de Rham spectral sequence.

This connection can be made precise. There is a square of spectral sequences, which stick together the four spectral sequences

If the HKR spectral sequence degenerates, then the Tate spectral sequence degenerating implies that the Hodge-de Rham spectral sequence degenerates. The HKR spectral sequence in turn degenerates if and only if Hochschild homology is formal as a dg-algebra (which says nothing about the formality as a dg-Lie algebra, which we saw was Kontsevich’s main result). In fact, Hochschild, Kostant and Rosenberg basically showed that the HKR spectral sequence does degenerate for smooth proper in characteristic zero, so Tate degeneration is the same as Hodge-de Rham degeneration.

Before proceeding, let’s again stop to recap. So far, we have seen that behaves exactly like the Bott element , and in a sense is nothing but the Bott element. Moreover, when applied to Hochschild homology and friends, this perspective tells us that -adic degeneration (which obstructs the existence of a deformation quantization of a Calabi-Yau variety) is exactly degeneration of the Tate spectral sequence, which in turn is exactly degeneration of the Hodge-de Rham spectral sequence.

The degeneration of the Hodge-de Rham spectral sequence is the starting point for Hodge theory. I’ll refer the reader to my notes here (see also here). The degeneration of the Hodge-de Rham spectral sequence can be categorified into the nonabelian Hodge correspondence. The de Rham side gets categorified into a certain subcategory of vector bundles with flat connection (namely, the semisimple bundles), and the Hodge side gets categorified into a certain subcategory of Higgs bundles (namely, the ones which are direct sums of Higgs bundles with the same slope, and which have vanishing first and second Chern classes).

The intermediary between these two categories is the world of (polystable) bundles with flat -connection. (Again, see my notes.) It is useful to think of a -connection on a vector bundle as a filtration on this bundle and a connection which satisfies Griffiths transversality with respect to this filtration. See this post for a discussion. Vector bundles with flat connection can be viewed as (-coherent) -modules, Higgs bundles as -modules, and vector bundles with flat -connection as -modules, where is the Rees construction on the order filtration on , and is our Rees construction variable.

From this point of view, we can look at the de Rham complex (which is a resolution of as a D-module) equipped with the Hodge filtration/the stupid filtration. This makes it a module with a flat -connection, where again we view -connections as filtrations + connection satisfying Griffiths transversality. Then, the Hodge-de Rham spectral sequence is nothing but the -adic spectral sequence.

Therefore, is nothing but (which we saw earlier is just the Bott element ). To fix the resulting weird grading in the statement of the nonabelian Hodge correspondence (where lives in degree ), we refer the reader to this post. For now, we can just think of this as a sort of “shearing”; but as we shall see, this is too naive of a perspective to be taking in characteristic /over the sphere spectrum. (So the title of this post is a bit misleading…) We’ll talk about this next time.

entry.title: Bott = Planck = sheared Rees
entry.content:
In this post (and presumably the following few, too, because I expect this to get quite long), I would like to talk about an idea that over the past six months has come to become a tenet of the way I think about quantum mechanics, Hodge theory, -actions, filtrations, etc. The core idea is expressed in the following equation:

Here, (denoted equivalently by ) is the degree Bott element in (where is a complex oriented ring spectrum); is the Planck constant; and is the parameter in “-connections” that encodes the order filtration on D-modules (or more generally the parameter appearing in the Rees construction of a filtered module), i.e., the Hodge filtration.

Here’s the plan for this post (these posts?). I’m going to try to give an exposition of (perturbative) quantum mechanics/field theory as motivation for deformation quantization; use that to say a bit about deformation quantization of symplectic manifolds from the modern point of view, as pioneered by Kontsevich; talk about how this is analogous to the degeneration of the Hodge-de Rham spectral sequence; briefly go over nonabelian Hodge theory (again!); then go back to the Hodge-de Rham spectral sequence and state what it’s got to do with Hochschild homology and circle actions, where we’ll see that the Bott element corresponds to the deformation parameter/”the Planck constant”. Then, we will use our equation relating , , and to discuss deformation quantization in characteristic from the more homotopically-flavored point of view; we’ll see that quantized algebras (following Bezrukavnikov-Kaledin) essentially come from -actions, and that restricted structures on quantized algebras can be viewed as the Dyer-Lashof operation . (In fact, we will see that cyclotomic spectra are the homotopical analogues of Frobenius-constant quantizations.) I haven’t tried to prove something like the Azumaya algebra property from Proposition 1.24 (see also Lemma 3.2) of their paper, but it should certainly be doable (although, as far as I understand, their techniques don’t really generalize to the homotopical setting).

We will start off in characteristic zero, and will switch over to characteristic later; in fact, until mentioned otherwise, you should just assume that the base field is .

Part one: /deformation quantization

Let’s begin with a review of quantum theory; there’s a lot to say here, so I will say only the minimal amount necessary to get to the math. It’s not really crucial to understand the physics if you’re willing to forego the motivation; if you don’t want to read the physics motivation, just skip down to where we start talking about Poisson brackets.

There are at least two approaches to time evolution in quantum mechanics: in the Schrodinger picture, the states evolve through time (as described by the Schrodinger equation), while the operators (like the Hamiltonian) remains constant; in the Heisenbeg picture, the states remain constant, while the operators evolve through time. In the Schrodinger picture, the equation of motion can be solved to give , where is a time evolution operator (which is , if the Hamiltonian is time-independent). In the Heisenberg picture, the state remains constant, while an operator evolves as . Using the Schrodinger equation, one can show that the the equation of motion in the Heisenberg picture is

(If has no time dependence, then the final term vanishes.) The upshot is that the dynamical variables in the Schrodinger picture are the states, while the dynamical variables in the Heisenberg picture are the operators.

Now, given a classical system, one can try to construct a corresponding quantum theory. There are many ways of doing so: for example, the Lagrangian formalism in classical mechanics can be quantized via the path integral formalism (which is the easiest to do calculations with, at least perturbatively, and which is equivalent to the Schrodinger and Heisenberg pictures); the Hamiltonian formalism in classical mechanics can be approached canonical quantization, where it can be studied via the Schrodinger and Heisenberg pictures. In canonical quantization, one promotes classical dynamical variables like position and momentum to operators. Geometric quantization (which I don’t understand) seems to focus on quantization via the Schrodinger picture, while deformation quantization focuses on the Heisenberg picture.

To motivate how deformation quantization focuses on the Heisenberg picture, recall that Hamilton’s equation of motion in classical mechanics states that if is a function on the phase space of our classical system (where is position, is momentum, and is time), then

Here, is the Poisson bracket (in canonical coordinates, it is ). The upshot is that, in the Heisenberg picture, the Poisson bracket is quantized to . So, if is a manifold equipped with a Poisson bracket, we might define a quantization of to be a product on (where is a formal variable) such that the commutator is given by

In the algebraic setting, if is a smooth variety with a Poisson bracket, then we can define a quantization to be a flat associative -algebra (with product denoted by ) such that , and satisfying the same commutator relation. For example, suppose is the formal affine plane , with Poisson bracket determined by the symplectic form . Then, a quantization is given by (in fact, this is the only quantization). Note that, in particular, setting takes us back to the classical world, just as one would expect from a physical point of view: at a scale when is tiny, quantum mechanical effects cease to be significant.

It is important to note that if you’re scourging the literature for perturbative expansions and you’re finding that just doesn’t appear anywhere, it’s because physicists set in quantum mechanical calculations. These are “natural units”, but, as we shall see when talking about Hodge theory, setting to has real mathematical content (even though it means having divergent formal power series expansions in quantum mechanics).

(Before I proceed, I’d just like to say that one can also observe that in the path integral approach also reduces to the classical story. Here’s a disappointing-even-to-physicists-level-of-rigor argument. If and are points, then the probability amplitude for a particle to go from to in a time is given by , where the integral is over the space of paths. Now, suppose that . Then, the contribution from two paths and do cancel each other out (constructively interfere) iff is approximately . Roughly, this means that and are close to each other, and is maximized at . So, as , there’s only one dominating contribution for the integral for the probability amplitude coming from a path which extremizes the action. By Euler-Lagrange, this is the classical trajectory of the particle. If you want to see a more precise discussion, the keyword here is “stationary phase approximation”, and essentially boils down to Taylor expanding the action around a critical point to the second order, combined with the fact that

which in turn can be proved by completing the square in the exponential and using the classical calculation of the integral of .)

Kontsevich’s theorem is that every Poisson manifold has a deformation quantization. In fact, he gave an explicit formula for the product as a perturbative expansion of a path integral via Feynman diagrams.

We won’t need to know the proof (because we’ll soon be talking about a different formality statement), but it is a great result, so we’ll sketch it anyway. A proof of Kontsevich’s theorem goes by reducing to showing that the Hochschild cochains are a formal dg-Lie algebra. Indeed, if is a smooth variety/manifold, then the HKR theorem says that the Hochschild cohomology of is quasi-isomorphic to the dg-algebra of polyvector fields on (i.e., ) with zero differential. The deformations of are controlled by the dg-Lie algebra given by the Hochschild homology with the Gerstenhaber bracket; namely, deformations of are classified by solutions to the Maurer-Cartan equation in this dg-Lie algebra. On the other hand, solutions to the Maurer-Cartan equation in with the usual Lie bracket are in bijection with Poisson structures on : if , then the Poisson bracket is given by . So, if the HKR quasi-isomorphism could be upgraded to a quasi-isomorphism of dg-Lie algebras, then we’d see that every Poisson structure on gives rise to a deformation of . (There’s an issue here, namely that the quasi-isomorphism of the HKR theorem doesn’t actually respect the bracket, but it can be corrected to one, in the sense that the first “Taylor coefficient” of the correction is the HKR map; see 4.6.2 here. These correction terms are where the path integral stuff comes from.)

By the Deligne conjecture, the Hochschild cochains admit the structure of an -algebra, and one can then formally reduce (ha) the desired formality statement (see here) to showing that the -operad is formal in characteristic zero. This was proved by Kontsevich (for the -operad in characteristic zero in general). As a remark, the homology of the -operad in characteristic zero encodes the structure of a Gerstenhaber algebra (where the Gerstenhaber bracket is given by the Browder bracket).

In the next post, we will talk about Hodge theory.

entry.title: Artin-Schreier sequences and motivic homotopy
entry.content:
In this post, I would like to record the following observation, whose origin I haven’t been able to track down, but I learnt it from Elden Elmanto and Robert Burklund, and Robert told me he learned it from Tom Bachmann. I think it probably dates all the way back to Voevodsky. The statement is the following: let be a smooth scheme of characteristic ; then, the -completion of the etale stable motivic category (where you replace Nisnevich sheaves by etale sheaves) is zero. The argument is as follows: the Artin-Schreier map , given locally by , has kernel given by the constant etale sheaf . Therefore, . This implies that multiplication by is invertible in , and so the -completion of this category is zero. In particular, is invertible in any -invariant etale sheaf of spectra on smooth -schemes.

This situation is pretty reminiscent of the story prior to the discovery of crystalline cohomology in the 60’s: -adic etale cohomology at the characteristic does not behave well. This leads one to hope that there may be a “crystalline” version of the etale stable motivic category for schemes of characteristic , which is better behaved in the sense that its -completion doesn’t just vanish. Based on our above discussion, we need to either discard -invariance or etale descent. Let’s keep -invariance, so we need to think of a replacement for etale descent.

The conceptual issue that I run into when thinking about this question is that etale cohomology is inherently constructible (locally constant sheaves and the like), while crystalline cohomology is inherently coherent. So (and this is true of both Weil cohomologies and the motivic category) over a base of characteristic , our objects of interest “degenerate” from the constructible world away from to the coherent world at . What we might look for, therefore, is an “object” interpolating between the constructible/etale world away from and the coherent/crystalline world at .

In the Weil cohomology theory world, there is such an object, described by BMS, using the ring . So, it is natural to ask: is there is a “” which specializes to (the -linearization of) ?

I talked briefly with Elden about this circle of ideas (who has a lot more ideas on this stuff; see also his recent paper here), and it seems like a pretty fun thing to think about.

entry.content:
In this post, I would like to discuss nonabelian Hodge theory in characteristic , and the possibility of homotopifying it. Unlike in characteristic zero, the correspondence here is entirely in the algebraic world. Let’s begin by discussing the classical results of Ogus and Vologodsky. Let be a smooth -algebra over a perfect field , and let be a flat lift of to with a lift of the Frobenius on . Let be a scheme over , along with a lift of to . Suppose, further, that the relative Frobenius over lifts to .

Then, Ogus and Vologodsky prove that there is an equivalence between the category of modules on with a flat connection and modules over with a Higgs field . The correspondence goes as follows.

  • Suppose is a module with a Higgs field over . The lift defines the Deligne-Illusie lift of the Cartier map, given by . The bundle over is then given by , and . Here, is the canonical Frobenius descent connection on .
  • Suppose is a module with flat connection over . Let denote the -curvature of ; this can be regarded as a map . Then, the connection has zero -curvature, and so by Cartier/Frobenius descent, the pair descends a bundle to . The Higgs bundle associated to is then .

We would like to understand this from the point of view of Hochschild homology. To begin with, suppose is of characteristic zero and is a smooth -scheme. Then, it was shown here that there is an equivalence of categories between and (this means a 2-periodic version of right D-modules). The proof of this result relies on two important non-formal statements: the formality of Hochschild homology in characteristic zero (which is related to the formality of ), and the Atiyah-Bott localization theorem.

Now, Preygel’s result can be refined a bit. Namely (again, is of characteristic zero), the equivalence refines to a filtered equivalence which keeps track of the Hodge filtration. Namely, there is an equivalence . Then, there is an equivalence between filtered coherent -modules and filtered coherent modules over (where this filtration comes from the -homotopy fixed points spectral sequence, so ). Taking the associated graded of this gives a -linear equivalence between -modules and -modules.

Preygel’s result is false in characteristic , because Hochschild homology is not formal. However, there is an analogue of this result, which can be stated as follows. Recall that admits a filtration whose th associated graded is . Negative cyclic homology is categorified by . This category admits an filtration, which comes from the filtered circle introduced here. Note that this category is -linear. Then, the analogue of Preygel’s result is the statement that the associated graded of this category is equivalent to as -linear categories. (Here, is the sheaf of crystalline differential operators.) We write this as . Just as in characteristic zero, there is a -linear equivalence between -modules and -modules.

So, from this point of view, the Ogus-Vologodsky equivalence can be ``two-periodified’’ to a -linear equivalence between (note that there is an equivalence ) and . It’s clear from phrasing this way that what we should be doing, in the case when is affine (say ), at least, is looking for a Cartier isomorphism compatible with the filtrations on both sides. This was proved here by Kaledin.

To make this homotopical, we would want a homotopical analogue of this statement (as well as the categorification, but let’s set our sights on a simpler goal for now). Namely, if is an -linear stable -category which lifts to (and satisfies some additional condition), we would like an equivalence . This is a generalization of Kaledin’s result to the categorical setting, but I don’t know how to prove it. By Proposition 2.15 here, there is a Frobenius linear equivalence , where is the degree generator of . So, we are reduced to showing that there is a (linear) equivalence for certain . More generally, we can ask for an equivalence between and for certain dualizable -modules in cyclotomic spectra.

I’m purposely being a little ambiguous here: I haven’t said exactly what means, but we can interpret it to mean ``Tate construction for the trivial -action on ’’. (What I’d like, for instance, is a relationship between (where acts trivially) and the localization of the free --algebra on a generator in degree , localized at the degree element (i.e., the localization of at the canonical degree element), where is some -ring. I believe the relationship should go as follows. By Proposition 5.4.9 here, the associated graded of the -Tate spectral sequence filtration on can be identified with the graded -algebra in Section 3.4 of Lurie’s paper. Then, there should be a canonical equivalence . If is actually a complex oriented ring, then the -Tate spectral sequence just collapses, and we get . So, in this case, we get an equivalence . This isn’t exactly the thing we wanted in the previous paragraph, but it certainly looks close.)

Anyway, I’m not sure if this is even the right approach to homotopifying the nonabelian Hodge correspondence in characteristic , but it seems interesting nonetheless.

In general, the story above fits into a general paradigm, where the deformation quantization parameter (which appears as the in “-connection”) can be equated with the Bott element . So, the homotopy-theoretic version of a deformation quantization is the datum of an -action. The degeneration of the -adic spectral sequence (i.e., the formality of the deformation quantization problem) is then the degeneration of the -fixed points spectral sequence. Setting (i.e., looking at the associated graded) amounts to killing the Bott element (i.e., looking at the underlying object on which -action), while setting amounts to looking at the -Tate construction. I’ll write about this in more detail later, but I did write a little bit about this perspective in Section 4 here.
